page.title: 06ECOLOGY FLORA
page.content: Chippenhall Green, Fressingfield, is a forty acre common, believed never to have been cultivated. It is at present grazed by cattle and horses from May to October.The common supports possibly the largest colony of green winged orchids in the British Isles. They are helped to survive by the Suffolk Trust for Nature Conservation who each summer send a party of volunteers and recruits from the Manpower Services Commission to remove thistles etc, the spread of which threatens the orchids and against which it is obviously impossible to spray. During late Autumn, Liberty Cap toadstools are to be found, which, when dried, give a similar effect to hallucinogenic drugs such as L.S.D. We have other small areas where wild flowers are conserved, ie the bee orchid,ragged robin and wild campanula
